metadata.title: Incident tasks - Microsoft Defender XDR Ransomware Playbook for SecOps
metadata.description: This playbook add Incident Tasks based on Microsoft Defender XDR Ransomware Playbook for SecOps. This playbook will walk the analyst through four stages of responding to a ransomware incident: containment, investigation, eradication and recovery, and prevention. The step-by-step instructions will help you take the required remedial action to protect information and minimize further risks.
postDeployment: 1. Add Microsoft Sentinel Responder role to the managed identity.
2. Assign playbook to the automation rule.

body.taskTitle: Containment - Step 1: Assess the scope of the incident

Compose_-_Containment_-_Step_1.inputs:
Containment and investigation should occur as simultaneously as possible; however, you should focus on quickly achieving containment, so you have more time to investigate. These steps help you determine the scope of the attack and to isolate it to only affected entities, such as user accounts and devices.
Run through this list of questions and tasks to discover the extent of the attack. Microsoft Sentinel and Microsoft 365 Defender can provide a consolidated view of all impacted or at-risk assets to aid in your incident response assessment. See Respond to threat actors while investigating or threat hunting in Microsoft Sentinel or Incident response with Microsoft 365 Defender. You can use the alerts and the evidence list in the incident to determine:
� Which user accounts might be compromised?
o Which accounts were used to deliver the payload?
� Which onboarded and discovered devices are affected and how?
o Originating devices
o Impacted devices
o Suspicious devices
� Identify any network communication that is associated with the incident.
� Which applications are affected?
� What payloads were spread?
� How is the attacker communicating with the compromised devices? (Network protection must be enabled):
o Go to the indicators page to add a block for the IP and URL (if you have that information).
o Add entities to threat intelligence in Microsoft Sentinel
� What was the payload delivery medium?

Compose_-_Containment_-_Step_2.inputs:
Run through this list of tasks and questions to protect existing systems from attack:
� If you have online backups, consider disconnecting the backup system from the network until you are confident that the attack is contained, see Backup and restore plan to protect against ransomware.
� If you are experiencing or expect an imminent and active ransomware deployment:
o Suspend privileged and local accounts that you suspect are part of the attack. You can do this from the Users tab in the properties of the incident in the Microsoft 365 Defender portal, or Investigate users with Microsoft Sentinel UEBA.
o Stop all remote logon sessions.
o Reset the compromised user account passwords and require the users of compromised user accounts to sign in again - Respond to threat actors while investigating or threat hunting in Microsoft Sentinel
o Do the same for user accounts that might be compromised.
o If shared local accounts are compromised, have your IT admin help you to enforce a password change across all exposed devices. Example Kusto query:
DeviceLogonEvents | where DeviceName contains (AccountDomain) | take 10
� For the devices that are not yet isolated and are not part of the critical infrastructure:
o Isolate compromised devices from the network but do not shut them off - Respond to threat actors while investigating or threat hunting in Microsoft Sentinel
o If you identify the originating or spreader devices, isolate those first.
� Preserve compromised systems for analysis.

Compose_-_Containment_-_Step_3.1.inputs:
Use this list to keep the attack from spreading to additional entities.
� If shared local accounts are being used in the attack, consider Blocking Remote Use of Local Accounts.
o Kusto query for all network logons that are local admins:
DeviceLogonEvents
| where IsLocalAdmin == true and AccountDomain == DeviceName
| extend IsLocalLogon = tobool(todynamic(AdditionalFields).IsLocalLogon)
| where IsLocalLogon==false
o Kusto query for non-RDP logons (more realistic for most networks):
DeviceLogonEvents
| where IsLocalAdmin == true and AccountDomain == DeviceName and LogonType != 'RemoteInteractive'
| extend IsLocalLogon = tobool(todynamic(AdditionalFields).IsLocalLogon)
| where IsLocalLogon==false
� Quarantine and add indicators for files that are infected.
� Ensure that your antivirus solution is configurable in its optimal protection state. For Microsoft Defender Antivirus, this includes:
o Real time protection is enabled.
o Tamper protection is enabled. In the Microsoft 365 Defender portal, select Settings > Endpoints > Advanced features > Tamper protection.
o Attack surface reduction (ASR) rules are enabled.
o Cloud protection is enabled.
Continue to the task - Containment - Step 3.2: Prevent the spread

Compose_-_Containment_-_Step_3.2.inputs:
� Disable Exchange ActiveSync and OneDrive sync.
o To disable Exchange ActiveSync for a mailbox, see How to disable Exchange ActiveSync for users in Exchange Online.
o To disable other types of access to a mailbox, see:
    - Enable or disable MAPI for a mailbox.
    - Enable or Disable POP3 or IMAP4 access for a user.
o Pausing OneDrive sync will help protect your cloud data from being updated by potentially infected devices. For more information, see How to Pause and Resume sync in OneDrive.
� Apply relevant patches and configuration changes on affected systems.
� Block ransomware communications using internal and external controls.
� Purge cached content

body.taskTitle: Eradication and recovery - Step 1: Verify your backups
Eradication and recovery - Step 2: Add indicators
Eradication and recovery - Step 3: Reset compromised users
Eradication and recovery - Step 4: Isolate attacker control points
Eradication and recovery - Step 5: Remove the malware
Eradication and recovery - Step 6: Recover files on a cleaned device
Eradication and recovery - Step 7: Recover files in OneDrive for Business
Eradication and recovery - Step 8: Recover deleted email
Eradication and recovery - Step 9: Re-enable Exchange ActiveSync and OneDrive Sync

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S1_.inputs:
<dt>If you have offline backups, you can probably restore the data that has been encrypted after you have removed the ransomware payload (malware) from your environment and after you have verified that there's no unauthorized access in your Microsoft 365 tenant.</dt>
<dt>Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 2: Add indicators</dt>

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S2_.inputs:
Add any known attacker communication channels as indicators, blocked in firewalls, in your proxy servers, and on endpoints, and add entities to threat intelligence in Microsoft Sentinel.
Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 3: Reset compromised users

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S3_.inputs:
Reset the passwords of any known compromised user accounts and require a new sign-in.
� Consider resetting the passwords for any privileged account with broad administrative authority, such as the members of the Domain Admins group.
� If a user account might have been created by an attacker, disable the account. Do not delete the account unless there are no plans to perform security forensics for the incident.
Respond to threat actors while investigating or threat hunting in Microsoft Sentinel
Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 4: Isolate attacker control points

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S4_.inputs:
Isolate any known attacker control points inside the enterprise from the Internet.
Respond to threat actors while investigating or threat hunting in Microsoft Sentinel
Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 5: Remove the malware

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S5_.inputs:
Remove the malware from the affected devices.
� Run a full, current antivirus scan on all suspected computers and devices to detect and remove the payload that is associated with the ransomware.
� Do not forget to scan devices that synchronize data or the targets of mapped network drives.
Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 6: Recover files on a cleaned device

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S6_.inputs:
Recover files on a cleaned device.
� You can use File History in Windows 11, Windows 10, Windows 8.1, and System Protection in Windows 7 to attempt to recover your local files and folders.
Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 7: Recover files in OneDrive for Business

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S7_.inputs:
Recover files in OneDrive for Business.
� Files Restore in OneDrive for Business allows you to restore an entire OneDrive to a previous point in time within the last 30 days. For more information, see Restore your OneDrive.
Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 8: Recover deleted email

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S8_.inputs:
In the rare case that the ransomware deleted all your email, you can probably recover the deleted items. See Recover deleted messages in a user's mailbox in Exchange Online.
Continue to Eradication and recovery - Step 9: Re-enable Exchange ActiveSync and OneDrive Sync

Compose_-_Eradication_and_recovery_-_S9_.inputs: <dt>After you have cleaned your computers and devices and recovered the data, you can re-enable Exchange ActiveSync and OneDrive sync that you previously disabled in step 3 of containment.</dt>

Compose_-_HumOR.inputs: You can get detailed information regards ransomware in Human-operated ransomware, as Microsoft best practices.

Compose_-_Introduction.inputs:
When you suspect you were or are currently under a ransomware attack, establish secure communications with your incident response team immediately. They can perform the following response phases to disrupt the attack and mitigate the damage:
NOTE: For information about preventing ransomware attacks, see Rapidly protect against ransomware and extortion.
Click on "Containment - Step 1: Assess the scope of the incident" task when you're ready to start.

body.taskTitle: Investigate - Identify the line of business (LOB) apps that are unavailable due to the incident
Investigation - Look for exposed credentials in the infected machines

Compose_-_Investigate_-_Identify_the_lin.inputs:
� Does the app require an identity?
o How is authentication performed?
o How are credentials such as certificates or secrets stored and managed?
� Are evaluated backups of the application, its configuration, and its data available?
� Determine your compromise recovery process.

Compose_-_Investigation_-_Assess_the_cur.inputs:
� What initially made you aware of the ransomware attack?
o If IT staff identified the initial threat�such as noticing backups being deleted, antivirus alerts, endpoint detection and response (EDR) alerts, or suspicious system changes�it is often possible to take quick decisive measures to thwart the attack, typically by the containment actions described in this article.
� What date and time did you first learn of the incident?
o What system and security updates were not installed on devices on that date? This is important to understand what vulnerabilities might have been leveraged so they can be addressed on other devices.
o What user accounts were used on that date?
o What new user accounts were created since that date?
o What programs were added to automatically start around the time that the incident occurred?
� Is there any indication that the attacker is currently accessing systems?
o Are there any suspected compromised systems that are experiencing unusual activity?
o Are there any suspected compromised accounts that appear to be actively used by the adversary?
o Is there any evidence of active command-and-control (C2) servers in EDR, firewall, VPN, web proxy, and other logs?

Compose_-_Investigation_-_Identify_the_r.inputs:
Using advanced hunting, search for this process in the process creation events on other devices. Run query in Advanced hunting.
You can use also DeviceProcessEvents table in Microsoft Sentinel Logs or in Microsoft 365 Defender advanced hunting.

Compose_-_Investigation_-_Look_for_expos.inputs:
� For user accounts whose credentials were potentially compromised, reset the account passwords, and require the users to sign in again.
� The following IOAs might indicate lateral movement:
o SuspiciousExploratoryCommands
o MLFileBasedAlert
o IfeoDebuggerPersistence
o SuspiciousRemoteFileDropAndExecution
o ExploratoryWindowsCommands
o IoaStickyKeys
o Mimikatz Defender Amplifier
o Network scanning tool used by PARINACOTA
o DefenderServerAlertMSSQLServer
o SuspiciousLowReputationFileDrop
o SuspiciousServiceExecution
o AdminUserAddition
o MimikatzArtifactsDetector
o Scuba-WdigestEnabledToAccessCredentials
o DefenderMalware
o MLSuspCmdBehavior
o MLSuspiciousRemoteInvocation
o SuspiciousRemoteComponentInvocation
o SuspiciousWmiProcessCreation
o MLCmdBasedWithRemoting
o Process Accesses Lsass
o Suspicious Rundll32 Process Execution
o BitsAdmin
o DefenderCobaltStrikeDetection
o DefenderHacktool
o IoaSuspPSCommandline
o Metasploit
o MLSuspToolBehavior
o RegistryQueryForPasswords
o SuspiciousWdavExclusion
o ASEPRegKey
o CobaltStrikeExecutionDetection
o DefenderBackdoor
o DefenderBehaviorSuspiciousActivity
o DefenderMalwareExecuted
o DefenderServerAlertDomainController
o DupTokenPrivilegeEscalationDetector
o FakeWindowsBinary
o IoaMaliciousCmdlets
o LivingOffTheLandBinary
o MicrosoftSignedBinaryAbuse
o MicrosoftSignedBinaryScriptletAbuse
o MLFileBasedWithRemoting
o MLSuspSvchostBehavior
o ReadSensitiveMemory
o RemoteCodeInjection-IREnabled
o Scuba-EchoSeenOverPipeOnLocalhost
o Scuba-SuspiciousWebScriptFileDrop
o Suspicious DLL registration by odbcconf
o Suspicious DPAPI Activity
o Suspicious Exchange Process Execution
o Suspicious scheduled task launch
o SuspiciousLdapQueryDetector
o SuspiciousScheduledTaskRegistration
o Untrusted application opens a RDP connection

Compose_-_Prevention_-_Device_protection.inputs:
The full list of prevention actions can be found in the ransomware threat analytics report, and in Rapidly protect against ransomware and extortion | Microsoft Docs
� Turn on Microsoft Defender Antivirus. (Execution)
� Turn on Microsoft Defender Firewall. (Lateral movement)
� Use advanced protection against ransomware. (Impact)
� Enable Network Protection in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint and Microsoft 365 Defender. (Initial access)
� Keep cloud-delivered protection in Microsoft Defender Antivirus turned on. (Defense evasion)
� Keep Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time behavior monitoring turned on. (Defense evasion)
� Turn on real-time protection. (Defense evasion)
� Turn on tamper protection in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, to prevent malicious changes to security settings. (Defense evasion)
� Update Microsoft Defender Antivirus definitions. (Lateral movement)

� Configure site and download checking in Microsoft Defender SmartScreen to block or warn. (Initial access)
� Configure app and file checking in Microsoft Defender SmartScreen to block or warn. (Initial access)
� Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus scanning of downloaded files and attachments. (Initial access)
� Block Win32 API calls from Office macros. (Execution)
� Migrate all legacy workbooks requiring Excel 4.0 macros to the updated VBA macro format. (Execution)
� Disable use of unsigned macros. Ensure all internal macros with business need are signed and leveraging trusted locations to ensure unknown macros will not run in your environment. (Execution)
� Stop malicious XLM or VBA macros by ensuring runtime macro scanning by Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) is on. This feature�enabled by default�is on if the Group Policy setting for Macro Run Time Scan Scope is set to Enable for All Files or Enable for Low Trust Files. Get the latest group policy template files. (Execution)
� Set Remote Desktop security level to TLS in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint and Microsoft 365 Defender. (Initial access)

Compose_-_Prevention_-_Email_management.inputs:
� Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus email scanning. (Initial access)
� Use Microsoft Defender for Office 365 for enhanced phishing protection and coverage against new threats and polymorphic variants. (Initial access)
� Check your Office 365 email filtering settings to ensure you block spoofed emails, spam, and emails with malware. Use Microsoft Defender for Office 365 for enhanced phishing protection and coverage against new threats and polymorphic variants. Configure Microsoft Defender for Office 365 to recheck links on click and delete delivered mails in response to newly acquired threat intelligence. (Initial access)
� Review and update to the latest?recommended settings for EOP and Microsoft Defender for Office 365 security. (Initial access)
� Configure Microsoft Defender for Office 365 to recheck links on click and delete delivered mails in response to newly acquired threat intelligence. (Initial access)

Compose_-_Prevention_-_Identity_protecti.inputs:
� Increase password security by:
o Using Azure AD Identity Protection to prevent and detect attacks and extend blocking of known weak passwords to on-premises Active Directory
o Extending Azure AD Password Protection to on-premises active directory
� Enforce strong multi-factor authentication (MFA) or passwordless logon for all users starting with administrators by using one or more of:
o Passwordless authentication with Windows Hello or Microsoft Authenticator app
o Azure Multi-Factor Authentication
o Third-party MFA solutions
� Practice the principle of least-privilege and maintain credential hygiene. Avoid the use of domain-wide, admin-level service accounts. Restricting local administrative privileges can help limit installation of RATs and other unwanted applications. (Privilege escalation)
� Enforce end-to-end session security. Explicitly validate the trust of users and workstations before allowing access to administrative interfaces using Azure AD Conditional Access.
� Enable Local Admin password management (Privilege escalation)
� Determine where highly privileged accounts are logging on and exposing credentials. Highly privileged accounts should not be present on workstations. (Privilege escalation)
� Disable the local storage of passwords and credentials. (Privilege escalation)

Compose_-_Prevention_-_Information_prote.inputs:
� Implement controlled folder access to help prevent files from being altered or encrypted by ransomware. (Impact)
o Set controlled folder access to Enabled or Audit mode.
� Back up important files regularly. Use the 3-2-1 rule. Keep three backups of your data, on two different storage types, and at least one backup offsite. (Impact)
� Use OneDrive cloud storage to protect and back up your files. (Impact)

Compose_-_Prevention_-_Vulnerability_man.inputs:
� Enable Automatic Updates. (Defense evasion)
� Ensure internet-facing assets have the latest security updates. Audit these assets regularly for suspicious activity. (Initial access)
